title: Are there any libraries that contain all books? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, and there probably never could be, considering the number of books in existence in every language from every location from every time period. Give you an idea of the scope - in the US alone, almost 1,000,000 books are published annually (that figure includes academic titles, self-published, etc.). If that figure holds true since the year 2000, we’ve already seen 17,000,000 books published in the US. The Library of Congress, which has been around for about 200 years, has approximately 167 million items on over 800 miles of shelves - and that’s not even close to everything in existence!

Yes. The Library of Babel is an online library which contains not only every book ( in English and within certain length constraints) ever written, but every book that could be written. It is based off of the concept/short story by Jorge Luis Borges also called The Library of Babel

The only one I can think of that comes closest is that in the United States it would be the Library of Congress. If one publishes a book in the United States, the Library of Congress controls giving out copyright. Part of that procedure is having a copy of the book at the Library of Congress. But that would just be US, not any other countries
No, but one day maybe the internet will.
Closest to contain all books written are the index in the Vatican and the US Congress library, with highest chance in the index
